tip: Bow instead of shaking hands when greeting.
Always remove shoes before entering homes, traditional inns, and some restaurants.
Be punctual; trains, tours, and meetings start exactly on time.
Keep your voice low in public spaces.
Carry cash; many small shops and temples don't accept credit cards.
Politeness is expected; use 'sumimasen' (excuse me) often.
Tipping is not practiced; attempting to tip may cause confusion.
Always queue in an orderly line for trains, buses, and shops.
Carry your trash; bins are scarce in Japan.
Use both hands when giving or receiving items, especially money or business cards.
Wash your hands and mouth at the purification fountain before entering a shrine.
Do not walk directly in the center under the torii gate; that space is reserved for deities.
At the offertory box, toss a coin, bow twice, clap twice, pray silently, then bow once more.
Respect 'no photography' signs; some sacred areas prohibit cameras.
Remove shoes when entering temple halls or tatami areas.
It is customary to ring the bell before praying at some shrines.
Small coin donations (5 yen is considered lucky) are appreciated.
Dress modestly when visiting religious sites.
Walk quietly and respectfully; avoid blocking pathways.
Expect crowds at New Year and festival days; behave patiently.
Do not wear swimsuits; bathe naked in onsen and sento.
Wash and rinse thoroughly before entering the bath.
Do not put your towel in the bath water; place it on your head or the side.
Some onsen forbid tattoos; check rules or use a cover sticker.
Keep voices low; onsen are for relaxation.
Photography is not allowed inside bathing areas.
Tie up long hair; do not let it touch the water.
Do not bring food or drinks into the bathing area.
Limit time in hot baths to avoid dizziness.
Mixed-gender baths exist but are rare; most are separated.
Do not stick chopsticks upright in rice; it resembles funeral rituals.
Do not pass food directly chopstick-to-chopstick; use a plate.
Slurping noodles is polite and shows appreciation.
Wait for everyone to be served before starting.
Say 'itadakimasu' before eating as a form of thanks.
Say 'gochisousama deshita' after finishing a meal to thank the cook.
Do not tip in restaurants; service charge is included.
Use the opposite ends of chopsticks when taking food from shared dishes.
Pay at the counter, not at the table, in many restaurants.
It is polite to refill others' glasses before your own.
Stay quiet on trains; phone calls are discouraged.
Do not sit in priority seats if elderly, disabled, or pregnant people are present.
Line up neatly when boarding trains or buses.
Take off backpacks or hold them low to avoid bumping others.
Stand on the left side of escalators in Tokyo, right side in Osaka.
Plastic bags cost extra; bring a reusable bag.
Place money in the tray at the cashier, not directly in hand.
Expect careful gift wrapping at stores, even for small items.
Receipts are often stamped or clipped to your bag as proof of purchase.
Tax-free shopping is available for tourists with passport; check minimum purchase rules.
